channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: G20 in final push to reach deal on climate at Rome summit
item.description: The leaders of the world's richest economies are looking for an agreement ahead of COP26.

item.title: 'I feel free' - LGBT Afghan refugees arrive in UK
item.description: The BBC speaks to one of 29 LGBT refugees who fled the Taliban, fearing for their lives.

item.title: Sudan coup: Three killed in protests against military takeover
item.description: Activists say security forces fired live rounds and tear gas at crowds, injuring around 100 people.

item.title: Yemen: Nine killed in Aden airport car bomb
item.description: The attack near Aden's airport is the deadliest to strike the temporary capital since last year.

item.title: Man dies during bull-running event in Spanish city of Onda
item.description: Authorities said the man suffered a head wound and had an artery punctured in his thigh by the bull.

item.title: 'Father of tiramisu' Ado Campeol dies aged 93
item.description: Campeol owned a restaurant in Italy where the dessert was invented by his wife and a pastry chef.

item.title: Israeli woman jailed three times for refusing to join the army
item.description: Most Jewish Israelis do military service. But a small number, like Shahar, take an ideological stance.

item.title: Alec Baldwin makes first public comments on 'one in a trillion' shooting
item.description: In his first public comments, the actor says the cinematographer he accidentally shot was his friend.

item.title: Saudi Arabia expels Lebanon ambassador amid Yemen row
item.description: The UAE, Kuwait and Bahrain also take diplomatic action in solidarity with the Saudis.

item.title: ICYMI: A baby rhino and million dollar trainers
item.description: A roundup of stories you might have missed this week, including a hoverbike and million dollar trainers.

item.title: Tonga records first coronavirus case since start of pandemic
item.description: The island nation was one of the last countries in the world not to have reported any infections.

item.title: â€˜As a child I saw the plane crash that killed my sisters'
item.description: Harriet was waving her sisters off when the plane left the runway and burned. Now she's finding others linked to the tragedy.

item.title: How the Taliban takeover changed my life
item.description: From office workers to students, Afghans share how their lives have changed since August.

item.title: The white student braving racial politics in South Africa
item.description: Jess Griesel faces a backlash for joining a party that backs the interests of poor black South Africans.

item.title: T20 World Cup: The toxic trolling of India's cricket stars
item.description: As online abuse becomes the main form of venting, many worry about the toxicity cricketers face on social media.

item.title: Marshall 'Major' Taylor: The first black American world champion & his fight to the top
item.description: Marshall 'Major' Taylor was the first black American to become a world champion, in 1899. This is his largely forgotten story.

item.title: Week in pictures: 23 - 29 October 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images from all over the globe, taken this week.

item.title: The 17-year-old making films fun for deaf children
item.description: Mariella, 17, made an app during lockdown that's helping some kids enjoy films for the first time.

item.title: Inside the controversial US gunshot-detection firm
item.description: BBC News has been given access to ShotSpotter, the controversial US technology company that detects gunshots.

item.title: Greta Thunberg: It's never too late to do as much as we can
item.description: Activist Greta Thunberg is still hopeful the world can achieve "massive changes" to combat climate change.

item.title: Japan undersea volcano: Artist tries to swim in floating pumice stone
item.description: An eruption from an undersea volcano has coated the coastal waters off a Japanese island in pumice.

item.title: The women reviving a vanishing legacy of Sufi music in Kashmir
item.description: This six-piece band has overcome a lot of opposition to be able to play Islamic devotional music.

item.title: La Palma: Living with lava
item.description: Residents on the Spanish island share how Cumbre Vieja's eruption has changed their lives.

item.title: The viral basketball star changing views on Muslim women in sport
item.description: Viral basketball sensation Jamad Fiin's videos have racked up millions of views online.

item.title: Can COP26 really save the planet?
item.description: Past COPs our science editor went to didn't stop climate change - will this one be any different?

item.title: Climate change: What's it like living in a place where it's 50C?
item.description: The BBC has spoken to people around the world about how extreme heat is changing their lives.

item.title: COP26: What effect does methane have on climate change? And more questions
item.description: BBC science correspondent Matt McGrath answers your questions about Glasgow's COP26 climate summit.

item.title: COP26: How Glasgow is hosting world leaders
item.description: About 120 world leaders from US President Joe Biden to the prime minister of Andorra will be in Glasgow for COP26.

item.title: What is climate change? A really simple guide
item.description: World temperatures are rising because of human activity, and climate change now threatens every aspect of human life.

item.title: COP26: African climate activists' message to world leaders
item.description: Young climate activists from Africa share their message to world leaders at COP26.
